item.title: Antony Blinken visits Ukraine to tout U.S. support for Kyiv's fight against Russia's advances
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken arrived in Kyiv on Tuesday in an unannounced diplomatic mission to reassure Ukraine that it has American support as it struggles to defend against increasingly intense Russian attacks.

media:content.media:text: Blinken arrived in Kyiv on Tuesday in an unannounced diplomatic mission to reassure Ukraine that it has American support as it struggles to defend against increasingly intense Russian attacks.
media:content.media:description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy greets U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken in Kyiv on May 14, 2024.

item.title: Recent Israeli troop movements seen by U.S. suggest Rafah attack could happen soon
item.dc:creator: Monica Alba and Courtney Kube and Gabe Gutierrez and Phil Helsel and Raf Sanchez and Reuters
item.description: The U.S. has seen recent troop movement that indicates Israel could expand operations in Rafah soon, but has not made a formal assessment about whether a full-scale invasion is imminent, according to two U.S. officials.

media:content.media:text: Israeli Strikes Destroy Buildings In Rafah
media:content.media:description: Children watch as smoke billows from buildings during Israeli strikes east of Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip on May 13, 2024.

item.title: King Charles unveils his first portrait since coronation at Buckingham Palace
item.dc:creator: Mirna Alsharif
item.description: Britain’s King Charles III unveiled a new portrait of himself at Buckingham Palace Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: King Charles III and Queen Camilla at the unveiling of artist Jonathan Yeo's portrait.
media:content.media:description: King Charles III and Queen Camilla at the unveiling of artist Jonathan Yeo's portrait of the King at Buckingham Palace, London, on Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: Artist Jonathan Yeo in front of the portrait of King Charles.
media:content.media:description: Artist Jonathan Yeo on Tuesday.

item.title: Jewish groups add more allegations of antisemitism to their lawsuit against UC Berkeley
item.dc:creator: Alicia Victoria Lozano
item.description: Two Jewish advocacy organizations suing the University of California, Berkeley, over a “longstanding, unchecked spread of anti-Semitism” have amended their complaint to include incidents from antiwar protests.

media:content.media:text: Erwin Chemerinsky smiles for a portrait
media:content.media:description: A lawsuit filed by Jewish advocacy groups alleges UC Berkeley tolerated an antisemitic campaign against its law school dean, Erwin Chemerinsky, seen here in 2021.

item.title: Duke students walk out of Jerry Seinfeld's commencement speech amid wave of anti-war protests
item.dc:creator: Doha Madani and Rebecca Cohen
item.description: Comedian Jerry Seinfeld was met with a wave of boos Sunday when students at Duke University in North Carolina walked out just before his commencement speech, the latest in a wave of antiwar protests at college graduations across the country this weekend.

media:content.media:text: Jerry Seinfeld
media:content.media:description: Jerry Seinfeld in Los Angeles on April 30, 2024.

item.title: Battles rage across Gaza as death toll tops 35,000 and tens of thousands evacuate Rafah
item.dc:creator: Hala Gorani and Mithil Aggarwal
item.description: Battles between Israeli forces and Hamas across Gaza after thousands people heeded evacuation orders to seek shelter elsewhere in the enclave.

media:content.media:text: Displaced Palestinians evacuate along a road of rubble
media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinians evacuate from the Tal al-Zaatar camp for Palestinian refugees in Gaza on May 11, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Smoke rises above damaged buildings
media:content.media:description: Smoke rises above buildings during an early morning Israeli strike on Rafah, Gaza, on Saturday.

media:content.media:text: Palestinian civilians flee Rafah in southern Gaza
media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinians transport their belongings on the back of a truck as they move to a safer area in Rafah, Gaza, on Thursday.

media:content.media:text: A Palestinian wounded in the Israeli bombardment of the Gaza Strip
media:content.media:description: A Palestinian wounded in the Israeli bombardment of the Gaza Strip is brought to a hospital in Rafah, Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Many Iranian Jews in 'Tehrangeles' say their allegiance is to Israel, not Iran
item.dc:creator: Alicia Victoria Lozano
item.description: As pro-Palestinian protesters clash with counter-protesters at U.S. colleges, among the most vocal defenders of Israel are members of the Iranian-Jewish community.

media:content.media:text: Photo collage of Abby Yosian and a campus counter-protest at UCLA
media:content.media:description: Abby Yosian, right, made a new friend from Israel, Charlotte Korchak, left, at an outdoor Passover seder near the University of Southern California.

item.title: Class destroyed: A look at what has become of Gaza's revered universities
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva and Yasmine Salam and Matthew Mulligan and Bianca Britton
item.description: Built over decades, Gaza’s universities embodied the ambitions of young Palestinians. In weeks, the Israeli military destroyed them.

item.title: U.S. citizens are languishing in Chinese prisons with little hope of release
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Jett and Abigail Williams and Dan De Luce and Rae Wang
item.description: As Secretary of State Antony Blinken visited China this week, the most important issue for hundreds of families in the U.S. was when their loved ones imprisoned in the country are coming home.

media:content.media:text: Nelson Wells Jr of Bossier City, La., who is currently detained in China.
media:content.media:description: Nelson Wells Jr. has been imprisoned in China for almost a decade.

item.title: They were promised jobs in Russia. They ended up fighting in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Muheet Ul Islam
item.description: Families of Indian migrant workers forced to fight alongside the Russian army in Ukraine say they feel they have no choice but to travel there to help them.

media:content.media:text: Indians hired to fight Russia's Ukraine war - 28 Feb 2024
media:content.media:description: Relatives of Azad Yousuf Kumar at his home in the Pulwama district of Indian-administered Kashmir in February.

media:content.media:text: Indians hired to fight Russia's Ukraine war - 28 Feb 2024
media:content.media:description: Raja Begum, Kumar’s mother, displaying his photo as he wears a military uniform.

item.title: China's stressed and overworked youth skip the tea and reach for coffee
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Jett and Dawn Liu and Rae Wang
item.description: China has overtaken in the U.S. with the most branded coffee shops in the world as young people start drinking coffee to cope with a competitive job market and workplace.

media:content.media:text: A barista prepares drinks at a coffee shop in Beijing on March 6th, 2024.
media:content.media:description: A barista prepares drinks at Metal Hands coffee shop in Beijing.

media:content.media:text: Li Yizhe turned to the energy boost of coffee to keep up with China's competitive work culture.
media:content.media:description: Li Yizhe turned to the energy boost of coffee to keep up with China's competitive work culture.

media:content.media:text: A patron works on a laptop at Metal Hands coffee shop in Beijing.
media:content.media:description: A patron works on a laptop at Metal Hands coffee shop in Beijing.

media:content.media:text: Wang Zichen, a former cafe owner, at SIP coffee in Beijing.
media:content.media:description: Wang Zichen, a former cafe owner, at SIP coffee in Beijing.

media:content.media:text: Wang Binqi at Mer coffee shop in Beijing.
media:content.media:description: Wang Binqi at Mer coffee shop in Beijing.

item.title: Blinken meets with Zelenskyy during unannounced Ukraine visit
item.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken met with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Kyiv during an unannounced diplomatic mission to reassure Ukraine that it has American support.

media:content.media:title: Blinken meets with Zelenskyy during unannounced Ukraine visit
media:content.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken met with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Kyiv during an unannounced diplomatic mission to reassure Ukraine that it has American support.

item.title: Billboard collapse in Mumbai kills at least 14 people
item.description: A billboard collapsed onto people during heavy rain and thunderstorms in India's western city of Mumbai, killing at least 14 and injuring 74 others. A rescue operation is ongoing, and it is unclear how many people may still be trapped.

media:content.media:title: Billboard collapse in Mumbai kills at least 14 people
media:content.media:description: A billboard collapsed onto people during heavy rain and thunderstorms in India's western city of Mumbai, killing at least 14 and injuring 74 others. A rescue operation is ongoing, and it is unclear how many people may still be trapped.

item.title: Museum curator accused of smuggling scorpion and spider samples
item.description: Lorenzo Prendini, an expert on arachnids at New York's American Museum of Natural History, was held by police at Istanbul Airport while allegedly trying to take about 1,500 samples out of the country.

media:content.media:title: Museum curator accused of smuggling scorpion and spider samples
media:content.media:description: Lorenzo Prendini, an expert on arachnids at New York's American Museum of Natural History, was held by police at Istanbul Airport while allegedly trying to take about 1,500 samples out of the country.

item.title: Israel fighting Hamas again in northern Gaza as hundreds of thousands flee Rafah
item.description: Israel is fighting a resurgence of Hamas militants in northern Gaza, while in the south, 360,000 people have fled Rafah to avoid Israeli strikes on the city. NBC News' Richard Engel reports.

media:content.media:title: Israel fighting Hamas again in northern Gaza as hundreds of thousands flee Rafah
media:content.media:description: Israel is fighting a resurgence of Hamas militants in northern Gaza, while in the south, 360,000 people have fled Rafah to avoid Israeli strikes on the city. NBC News' Richard Engel reports.

item.title: Nemo's Eurovision win fires up Swiss advocates for nonbinary rights
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Swiss advocates for nonbinary rights hailed Nemo’s victory in Eurovision Song Contest, urging authorities to enable official recognition of nonbinary people.

media:content.media:text: Swiss singer Nemo
media:content.media:description: Swiss singer Nemo at Eurovision Song Contest on May 11, 2024, in Malmo, Sweden.

item.title: LGBTQ people in the E.U. face less discrimination but more violence, survey finds
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, intersex and queer people in the European Union face less discrimination but more physical or sexual attacks than three years ago.

media:content.media:text: Participants wave rainbow fans during the pride parade
media:content.media:description: The Marseille Pride March in Marseille, France, in 2023.

item.title: Manhunt launched in France after 2 prison guards are killed in inmate escape
item.dc:creator: Nancy Ing and Elie Petit and Patrick Smith
item.description: A manhunt has been launched for armed attackers who killed two prison officers and injured three more while breaking a prisoner out of a van in northern France.

media:content.media:text: A forensic investigator at the site of a ramming attack in France
media:content.media:description: A forensic investigator at the site of a ramming attack Tuesday in Incarville, northern France.

item.title: Ongoing Brazil floods raise specter of climate migration
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Devastating and ongoing flooding in southern Brazil is forcing some of the half million displaced residents to consider uprooting their lives in one of the biggest cases of climate migration in Brazil's recent history.

media:content.media:text: A man rows a boat on a flooded street in Brazil
media:content.media:description: A man rows a boat on a flooded street Saturday in Sao Leopoldo, Rio Grande do Sul state, Brazil.

media:content.media:text: A flooded road in Brazil
media:content.media:description: A flooded road Monday in Canoas, Rio Grande do Sul state.

media:content.media:text: A worker cleans a street with a backhoe in Mucum, Brazil
media:content.media:description: A worker cleans a street Friday with a backhoe in Muçum.

media:content.media:text: Residents remove their belongings from their flooded homes in Brazil
media:content.media:description: Residents remove belongings from their flooded homes Monday in Canoas.

media:content.media:text: Flood waters inundate the streets of the Ipanema neighborhood
media:content.media:description: Flood waters inundate the streets of the Ipanema neighborhood Monday in Porto Alegre, Rio Grande do Sul state.

item.title: Georgian parliament approves divisive Russia-style bill that sparked weeks of mass protests
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: The Georgian parliament on Tuesday approved in the third and final reading a divisive bill that sparked weeks of mass protests.

media:content.media:text: Georgian parliament approves divisive Russia-style bill that sparked weeks of mass protests
media:content.media:description: Georgian demonstrators protesting the controversial "foreign influence" near the parliament building in Tbilisi on Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: Georgia's parliament on Tuesday began the third and final reading of a divisive bill that sparked weeks of mass protests, with critics seeing it as a threat to democratic freedoms and the country's aspirations to join the European Union.
media:content.media:description: Georgian lawmakers fighting during a parliament session in Tbilisi on Tuesday.

item.title: Incestuous rapist Josef Fritzl allowed to move to regular prison by court in Austria
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: A court in Austria said it had ruled that incestuous rapist Josef Fritzl, could be transferred to a regular prison from a prison psychiatric unit.

media:content.media:text: Austrian incest-rapist Josef Fritzl is being transferred to regular prison
media:content.media:description: Defendant Josef Fritzl at court in St. Poelten, Austria in 2009.

item.title: U.S. orders Chinese-backed crypto miner to sell land near nuclear missile base in Wyoming
item.dc:creator: Dylan Butts, CNBC
item.description: President Joe Biden ordered a Chinese-backed cryptocurrency mining company to sell land near a Wyoming nuclear missile base, citing national security concerns.

media:content.media:text: Missles standing near Gate 1 at the Francis E Warren Air Force Base in Cheyenne, WY
media:content.media:description: Francis E. Warren Air Force Base in Cheyenne, Wyo.

item.title: Russia defense scandal deepens with arrest of new bribery suspect
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: The head of personnel at Russia’s Defense Ministry has been arrested on suspicion of bribery after more than $1 million in cash and valuables were discovered at his properties, investigators said on Tuesday.

media:content.media:credit: Russian Defense Ministry via AP file
media:content.media:text: Russian defense ministry’s head of HR detained on suspicion of bribery
media:content.media:description: Russian Lt. Gen. Yuri Kuznetsov during a military parade in Krasnodar in 2021.

item.title: Russian president Putin to make a state visit to China this week
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin will make a two-day state visit to China this week, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin
media:content.media:description: Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin in Beijing in October.

item.title: Army whistleblower who exposed alleged Australian war crimes in Afghanistan is sentenced to prison
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: An Australian judge sentenced a former army lawyer to almost six years in prison for exposing allegations of Australian war crimes in Afghanistan.

media:content.media:text: McBride, 60, was sentenced to five years and eight months in prison after pleading guilty to three charges including theft and sharing with members of the press documents classified as secret.
media:content.media:description: Former army lawyer David McBride arriving at court in Canberra, Australia, on Tuesday.
